sn4.16:4.2: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dharma talk on the topic of the five grasping masses.
sn4.16:4.3: And those mendicants were paying attention, focusing, concentrating, and listening well.
sn4.16:5.2: “This ascetic Gotama is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dharma talk on the topic of the five grasping masses.
sn4.16:5.3: And the mendicants are paying attention, focusing, concentrating, and listening well.
sn4.16:5.4: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”
sn4.16:6.1: At that time many alms bowls were placed in the open air.
sn4.16:6.2: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of an ox and approached those bowls.
sn4.16:6.3: Then one of the mendicants said to another:
sn4.16:6.4: “Mendicant, mendicant, that ox will break the bowls.”
sn4.16:6.5: When this was said, the Buddha said to that mendicant:
sn4.16:6.7: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!”
sn4.16:6.8: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:
sn4.16:7.3: ‘I am not this’ and ‘this is not mine’;
sn4.16:7.4: that’s how to lose interest in them.
sn4.16:8.3: though Māra and his army chase everywhere
